cab.content: MINISTRY OP PENSIONS.\n -:--JL4 b $D Summary of Report LXX for period from May 18thto May 24th, 1918.Number of Pensions. 11273 pensions and allowances have been granted during the week to Officers and Men and to widov-s, children, ana dependants. The number since the beginning of the war is 1,347,319.2. Pensions to Soldiers. During the week out of 3568 cases (including lV3 rejectea under previous Warrants) dealt with by the Awards to Soldiers Branch 2798 were awarded pensions, permanent or temporary, 728 were granted gratuities, and 42 were rejected.^* Allowances in non-attributable oases. The procedure has been altered and these allowances, to which children1s allowances are added, will correspond with the degree of disability of the man. The period over which these allowances extend will depend upon the length and character of the man's service.4. Reboarding on ground of increased disability. A circular has been issued with a view (1) to avoid delay and (2) to warn Local Committees to use caution in exercising their powers..5. Pensions to Widows and Dependants. During the Week 1279 widows (including unmarried wives), 1186 parents and 29 other dependants were awarded pensions and 2139 children of widows and motherless &c. children were granted allowances.6. New Scheme of Pensions to Parents. During the Week the pre-?mr dependence of 46 parents" who were in pecuniary need have been raised from an average of 5/10 a week to an average of 11/6 whilst 56 unpensioned parents in pecuniary need have been granted an average pension of 9/3 a week. 65 cases have been refused pension.7. Alternative Pensions . Up to date 26 permanent and 715 conditional alternative pensions have been awarded to disabled men and 246 men under treatment and training are receiving alternative pension allowances.As a result of 3938 claims of war-widows for alternative pensions there have been 2145 awards and 778 rejections.8t Pensions Appeal Tribunal * Out of a total of 9405 claims 4436 cases have been finally disposed of.9* Retired Pay to Officers, &c, The review of grants to officers &c. under the Warrant of 1st August, 1917, and the Orders in Council of 29th September, 1917, will be completed next week.TREATMENT.10' U'se of Poor Law Institutions. Some of the Institutions offered are reported to be unsuitable for the purposes of the Ministry.11. Treatment of Orthopaedics. The question of additional accommodation at Belfast and West Hartlepool is under consideration.Proposals for the Erection of Annexes at 4 Military Orthopaedic Hospitals are about to be put before the War Office.12. Treatment of jveurasthenics. Under the Country'House Scheme 45 men have been boarded out privately. It is not yet possible to say how far the scheme will be a success. Treatment of Tuberculosis. Treasury Sanction has been obtained for various purposes in connection with the treatment and. after-care of tuberculous men.General Hospital Treatment at. Birmingham. Negotiations are on foot to acquire Lodge Road Hospital 7.1th accommodation for 200 in- . ' patients .15. Arrangements w1th Hospitals. Only a few arrangements are now being made directly with the Ministry.00"16. Numbers under Treatment. During the week 1^314 cases were admitted for treatment' in.or'at institutions, 761 were discharged and 17.603 cases were under treatment at the end of the week. The total number of men reported as having been or still being under treatment is 34,638.17. Refusal to undergo Treatment. There were 44 new cases in the week 24 accepted treatment, after warning and 13 refused an operation. Ho penalties were imposed.TRAINING.18. Trade Advisory Committees. Local Committees for the Building Trade sat in London, Manchester and Liverpool, At High Wycombe a Committee has been formed for Air-craft manufacture.Training Allowances. Further complaints as to the inadequacy of these"""aliowances have been received, k proposal to assist men as to board and lodging is awaiting Treasury Sanction.20. Training in Technical Institutes. The Board of Education Arrangements are being simplified as to procedure.21, Training of Disabled Men as Teachers. The Dudley Education Committee nave offered to train men at their Training Institute.22. Delay in placing men in training at Birmingham. A plan has been put forward to obviate the delay caused by the interviewing of applicants for training.23. Training Schemes. During the week 11 out of 17 schemes submitted by Local Committees have been sanctionedi; 66 individual cases outside approved schemes v/ere sanctioned and 213 men were admitted to and 69 discharged from training. The total number of men under training at the end of the week was 4,178.. Up to date 6,725 men have been or are still under training, exclusive of 730 men in training under the Ministry of Munitions.ORGANIZATION.24..
